Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Thin-Film Chalcogenide Glass Materials for High-Quality Integrated Photonics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: The main objectives of this collaborative research project between MIT and Washington University are (1) to develop critical understandings of the optical loss mechanisms in thin-film chalcogenide glass materials through spectroscopic studies, (2) to exploit innovative processing science to synthesize ultra-low-loss chalcogenide glass materials in the thin-film form and (3) to fabricate optical devices with novel functionalities. Based on these fundamental findings, the research aims to demonstrate chalcogenide glass resonant cavity devices with high quality factors as building blocks for photonic sensors, light emitters and nonlinear optical signal processing systems. The research is expected to have significant impacts on many areas including materials science, nanotechnology, nonlinear optics and integrated photonics. The participating undergraduate and graduate researchers benefit from the cross-disciplinary collaboration between the two research groups at MIT and Washington University. Results obtained from the research are incorporated into new undergraduate courses on glass materials at MIT. The project also expands K-12 initiatives on both campuses through lab open houses and summer internship programs.

Technical Description: Chalcogenide glasses (ChGs) are recognized as an emerging material platform for integrated photonics given their unique properties, such as substrate-blind integration capacity, extreme processing versatility, widely tunable optical and thermal characteristics via composition alloying, large Kerr nonlinearity, and broadband optical transparency. Unlike silica glass, multi-component chalcogenide glasses contain a far more diverse group of nanoscale glass network moieties. These properties result in complicated structural transformations and optical losses that are highly sensitive to processing history and cannot be described using the classical Rayleigh scattering formalism. As a consequence, traditional loss reduction methods cannot be simply transferred to chalcogenide materials without an in-depth understanding of the kinetics of micro-structural evolution and loss mechanisms in chalcogenide films. The challenge of differentiating optical loss contributions in chalcogenide films is further compounded by the small interaction volume in thin films, which severely limits the sensitivity of most traditional optical characterization methods. In this project, new waveguide- and resonator-based spectroscopic characterization methods are developed to extract critical material information such as nanoscale phase composition, intrinsic absorption, and different scattering processes. The project advances our understanding of the nanoscale structural transformation mechanisms associated with material's optical characteristics as well as the structure-processing-property relationship in ChG materials. By combining kinetic modeling and experimental validation of novel surface-tension-assisted processing techniques, the project also aims to develop ultra-high-quality planar ChG structures with performance exceeding the current state-of-the-art.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chalcogenide glasses (ChGs) have been recognized as an emerging material platform for integrated photonics for their large Kerr nonlinearity, broadband optical transparency in the infrared spectrum, and diverse properties that can be tailored by chemical compositions. Suppressing optical absorption and scattering loss in ChG glasses is of great importance to achieve high-quality photonic devices. A fundamental understanding of the loss mechanisms associated with nanoscale structures inside the glasses is important for us to modify the fabrication process in order to improve the optical quality of the ChGs. For example, thermal treatment could help mitigate nanoscale phase segregations, which is one of the main sources of optical loss in ChGs. However, it's challenging to characterize changes in materials in nanoscale using conventional characterization tools, especially when the changes require the control of such factors as temperature, humidity, and pressure. The resonator technology developed in this project will provide a new tool to characterize the properties of materials that cannot be easily approached using conventional instruments. 

Intellectual merit: Through this project, the PI developed and demonstrated a new tool to characterize dynamic processes with nanoscale spatial and microsecond temporal resolution in materials by using a high-quality whispering-gallery-mode (WGM) resonator coupled with a fiber-taper waveguide. The strong optical confinement and resonance enhancement of light-matter interactions in ultra-high-quality optical WGM resonators make it possible to develop an ultrasensitive material spectroscopic characterization tool. In particular, the absorption coefficients could be characterized and derived from the frequency shift and linewidth broadening of resonances in the transmission spectra of the resonator; while the scattering properties due to defects and material inhomogeneity that may arise from crystallization, incomplete glass transition, and fractures occurring in the thermal treatments are reflected by the splitting of optical modes. Our fundamental understanding of the material properties through the resonator assisted spectroscopic characterization tool will also help us to develop novel photonic devices with new or advanced functionalities in the future.

Broader impacts: This research lays the foundation for us to develop high-quality whispering-gallery-mode resonator based spectroscopic techniques suitable for thin film optical characterizations and generally applicable to different material systems. The scientific research are integrated in curriculum development, undergraduate student training, and development of hands-on educational modules. The interdisciplinary research program provides excellent education and research opportunities for students from different disciplines including materials science, electrical engineering, physics and photonics.
